doc.after: Proto-Germanic, also called Common Germanic or Ur-Germanic, is the unattested, reconstructed proto-language of all the Germanic languages, which include such diverse tongues as English, German, Dutch, the North Germanic languages such as Norwegian, Danish, Swedish, Icelandic, and Faroese, and the East Germanic languages such as Gothic.[1] By definition, Proto-Germanic is the stage of the language constituting the most recent common ancestor of the attested Germanic languages. Proto-Germanic is itself descended from Proto-Indo-European (PIE).
